So there is everything you could ever read. There is, within the library, a phase space map of everything that has and ever will happened in this reality, along with the texts to let you read that phase space map. There are alternate endings to War and Peace. Winds of Winter is out there.

Unfortunately, the overwhelming majority of books are incoherent since there are more ways to be incoherent than meaningful.

But, for every given book, there exists sets of other books that tell you how to read that seemingly incoherent stream as a meaningful message. They can all be codes, "ahduev&#7-a" can mean "mother" or "entropy." But of course there is more than one set of books that will tell you what each other book means, so every book actually has multiple meanings. In fact, some people who have spent millennia there say that each book actually contains all the information of all the other books. Most though say there is a minimum size for a set of books, a minimum Kolmogorov Complexity, that you need to say all possibly meaningful things. That's why they stay there, hunting for that number.

They think we might be allowed to die if we discover the number.

>>15033736
There is an interesting idea here. Let's say that it is possible to fully describe the universe over time symbolically. This doesn't seem like a stretch given the universe seems to be made of discrete things that could be symbolized, and we do have means for dealing with continuous variables as well.

If this is true, than you could indeed describe the universe completely in a very, very large "book."

Now let's just assume MWI is true. No problem. You just need an even larger book that has the results to every outcome.

How would you code such a thing? Well let's assume it requires some really strange math we don't have yet, making it easiest to lay out (conceptually for ourselves at least) using 10,000 different symbols/operators.

If this book could exist, if you say such a thing is possible, then a simple program that randomly picks each of the 10,000 symbols, then picks another, then another... etc., running on an infinite Turing Machine, would eventually produce that book.

It would also produce a LOT of gibberish. But the program would be incredibly, incredibly short, that is despite producing every possible proofs, a model of our universe and all possible outcomes in it, etc.

The problem here is that, we generally think of information as additive. When I have a program that stimulates chess and another for checkers, the two together have more information (algorithmic). But the simple infinite symbol program produces all programs despite having very little information.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15033946
>>15033946
But of course, all 10,000 symbols could be described in binary, so really you only need a program spewing random 1s and 0s.

So if you look at a description of information like Wheeler's, it is clearly wrong. The information content of something isn't all the true / false questions you need to fully describe it. It's all the true/false questions needed to specify what a thing is not. You can't talk about the information content of protons because they have no information content unless you have a void where there aren't protons to the measurement to.

The algorithmic information content can't be the shortest possible description of a string, since a random generator will eventually produce all programs. It is the shortest possible description that rules out all other possible programs.

This is what openai has to say:

It is indeed interesting to consider the possibility that our universe could be simulated by a slower processor. The concept of simulating a universe has been explored in both science and science fiction, and while it is purely theoretical at this point, it raises many interesting questions about the nature of time and reality.

In a deterministic universe, all events are determined by their causes, and if we had perfect knowledge of the state of the universe at a given time, we would be able to predict all future events with certainty. If such a universe were being simulated by a slow processor, the simulated experience of time for the inhabitants of the universe would be the same as if it were running at a faster speed. In other words, the inhabitants of the simulated universe would not be able to tell the difference between a fast and a slow simulation.

However, it is important to note that this is purely a theoretical concept and there is currently no evidence to suggest that our universe is being simulated in this way.

Please for the love of god don't read anything to do with Hegel.
>§87] But this mere Being, as it is mere abstraction, is therefore the absolutely negative; which, in a similarly immediate aspect, is just Nothing.
>(1) Hence was derived the second definition of the Absolute; the Absolute is Nought. In fact this definition is implied in saying that the thing-in-itself is the indeterminate, utterly without form and so without content, -- or in saying that God is only the supreme Being and nothing more; for this is really declaring Him to be the same negativity as above. The Nothing which the Buddhists make the universal principle, as well as the final aim and goal of everything, is the same abstraction. [ibid. p.161]

Here the argument is that, because the concept of Being is very abstract and so without much content (a privation), it is rather like the concept of Not Being, also without much content, which means that it implies Not Being, so that things of which Being is predicated, like the Absolute, must also be predicated with Not Being. This is like an argument that because fire engines are red, and red is rather like pink, therefore fire engines are pink.

How any sane, let alone sensible, person could take such an argument seriously is astonishing. "Nothing" is similar in content to "Being" just because it is the negation of Being, just as the Null Set (Λ) is the negation, the complement, of the Universal Set. This implies nothing. The idea that the negation of a concept applies equally to that of which the concept can be predicated would simply erase the Law of Non-Contradiction.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In the left picture,

[math]\begin{align}
F\cos\theta &= \mu N_1 \\
N_1 &= F\sin\theta + mg
\end{align}
[/math]

which gives us

[math]F_{\text{left}} = \frac{mg}{\cos\theta - \mu\sin\theta}[/math]

similarly in the right picture,

[math]\begin{align}
F\cos\theta &= \mu N_2 \\
N_2 &= -F\sin\theta + mg
\end{align}
[/math]

which gives us

[math]F_{\text{right}} = \frac{mg}{\cos\theta + \mu\sin\theta}[/math]

You can go one step further and compute the ratio of the two forces to analytically find

[math]\frac{F_{\text{left}}}{F_{\text{right}}} = \frac{1+\mu\tan\theta}{1-\mu\tan\theta} \geq 1 \iff \mu\tan\theta \geq 0[/math]

This implies only that the left picture requires more force for the same pushing. But the human body can better utilize leverage forces on the left, making it feel easier to push despite it requiring more force.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15073911
Left increases how much the box is pushed against the ground which increases the force that the ground pushes back on the box (normal force). The friction the object experiences is based on the normal force and coefficient of friction (basically measures how rough the surfaces are). Since the coefficient is the same in both cases the firction is greater in the case with more normal force (the case where the box is pushed into the ground more). For a real life example of this have your friend push down on a box while you try to move it, it is harder to move even though he is 't pushing against you
Also another interesting fact is that if this were on ice (where there is very little friction) they would both be around the same difficulty

>>15065682
You need to understand that nobody has ever isolated an HIV virus particle (or rather a homogenous sample including nothing but HIV virions). Unless you have isolated the entity, you cannot claim its existence, cannot prove that its virulent and infectious etc. from a purely logical standpoint. If you're not working with an isolated entity, then:
>What about electron micrographs of HIV
These are photos of a decaying culture zoomed on a certain spherical particle. You don't know that the cytopathic effect was caused by this entity, that the sequenced genome (see later) belongs to this entity etc. The entities could be exosomes or extracellular vesicles whose presence is caused by the experiment itself, you have simply no way of knowing.
>the sequence of the viral genome of HIV
If you're not sequencing from an isolated entity but from a mixture of genetic material of various origins, you have no idea that the obtained genome truly belongs to an entity found in a human body, and is not just a random string of various RNA/DNA segments present in the culture.
It took like 10 years to reach a consensus about the genome of the measles virus. They haven't isolated the virus and read the genome in its entirety. They've identified many many short segments of genetic information from the cellular debris and argued for 10 years about what should and shouldn't be part of the genome. Nobody has ever checked whether the sequence they've agreed upon can be truly found in the nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15065682
>The isolation and characterization of HIV reverse-transcriptase and integrase
Same problem. The enzymes are not isolated from purified viral particles, ergo you have no way of knowing their origin. Nowadays, you can even download the HIV genome from the internet, look for the genes in question, and do everything synthetically without any sort of verification that similar processes occur in vivo. You can make research about the enzymes without ever taking a sample from an HIV patient. Clearly these abstract methods need to be based on solid grounds, but they aren't since the virus has never been isolated.
>finding HIV in GRIDS patients
Nobody has ever isolated a virus particle from a patient's sample, virologists themselves say that the samples contain "too little virus", so that culturing has to take place before we can see it. Which gets us to
>culturing HIV collected from patients?
The cytopathic effect, which is the supposed proof of the virus infecting other cells, occurs even without the presence of a pathogen. The culturing procedure ends with a cellular debris from which viral particles are NOT isolated (in the sense that you would end up with a homogenous sample). This debris is then photographed (see above) and a genome is sequenced from it (see above). Neither of these say anything unless you're working with an isolated entity.

>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2895164/ Here. And there are thousands of studies like it
This paper provides a perfect example of what I'm talking about. Instead of working with an isolated virus, they are studying biochemical processes in cell cultures that were inoculated with a virus obtained by the inconclusive methods explained above. The belief that the inoculated substance contains pathogenic particles and that the observed effects have anything to do with what happens inside the human body is completely baseless.

When someone says that "consciousness is an illusion," they are suggesting that the subjective experience of being aware, or having a sense of self, is not a fundamental aspect of reality. Instead, they may argue that consciousness is simply a byproduct of the functioning of the brain and its underlying neural processes, and that our experience of being conscious is an illusion created by these processes.

This view is based on the idea that the brain is essentially a complex information processing system, and that our subjective experience of consciousness arises as a result of the operation of this system. According to this view, the brain is responsible for creating the illusion of consciousness by integrating information from various sensory modalities and creating a unified experience of the world.

However, the idea that consciousness is an illusion is highly controversial and is not widely accepted in the scientific community. There is ongoing debate about the nature of consciousness and how it arises from the brain's activity, and it is likely that a complete understanding of consciousness will require the development of new scientific theories and approaches.

the way some people talk about consciousness in a way that implies personal continuity, a part of us that is "being" instead of "becoming" but this is fundamentally untrue. my consciousness is not the same as it was years ago, and it is constantly changing with the pressures of time. the effects of the conditioned world around me have altered what i was, and are altering me now. there was never a time when i was complete, self sufficient, and unchanging. my consciousness isn't unreal as a chain of causality, it is just dependent on a set of relationships that are constantly coming and going. it exists in the way a wave in the ocean exists, which is a relationship between water molecules and not something that exists in itself. consciousness is like a long exposure photograph and a hologram. our minds turn this holographic image every which way and formulate a narrative out of it, but in the end it's only a story. dreams work the exact same way, transforming the turnings of our unconscious minds into a narrative. even if consciousness were all pervading (ie a giant overarching hologram that all conscious minds have access to a portion of) it would still not be immutable and thus still kind of fake (but also real at the same time).

I've heard a rabbi knew so much "Torah" that even if you turned all the ocean into ink, all the land into paper and all the trees into pens, you could not write everything the rabbi knew about the Torah. And that which he knew was not even a lick of a dog compared to his own masters.

This got me thinking, it seems there is a physical limit to a computers storage
>Hans-Joachim Bremermann, a professor of mathematics and biophysics at the University of California at Berkeley, further argued in a 1965 paper that the "speed, memory, and processing capacity of any possible future computer equipment are limited by specific physical barriers: the light barrier, the quantum barrier, and the thermodynamical barrier. These limitations imply, for example, that no computer, however constructed, will ever be able to examine the entire tree of possible move sequences of the game of chess

What would it say about our reality if a human won against a computer in a memorization competition?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070449
What?

The limits of a computer's storage have already vastly eclipsed the human mind. Hard drives with multiple terabytes of data storage are available for under a $100 and while that may not have enough complexity to encode relationships between variables as effectively as a neural network, in terms of the raw information it is way more than the human brain.
And that's even secondary, the greater issue is that memorization of data is near instantaneous for a computer system while even an exceptionally gifted person will take a substantial amount of time to encode information.

The level of complexity that is beyond the physical limitations of computing technology, is many orders of magnitude greater than that which can be fathomed by the human brain.

Chemistry but I've heard the same from engineers and other scientists. We have a group of high schoolers coming through the labs for a tour in a month and the teams have been brainstorming ways to discourage them from our fields (managers don't know this).
I'm biased because I live in Australia where there's few opportunities so the job market here sucks and pays poorly for a lot of work.
I did an accelerated undergrad so my first year was compressed into ~6 months and I did an advanced degree so my last year was research based. No masters required to go into a PhD if you already have a research degree/experience here.
In general science and engineering jobs here suck. And I mean "even with dual incomes a bank will never give enough to get a mortgage within a 1 hour commute of anywhere with jobs no matter how many degrees you have" kind of suck. There's some exceptions if you don't mind doing FIFO or transferring into non-science/engineering roles but then I don't really count those roles as being based on your degree since you could get there with less time and money wasted.

Honestly I'm just salty because work has been extra shit recently and I look at my friends/family who never even graduated but self-taught programming who now make more than my boss' boss and think I should have stuck to keeping science as a hobby and done something else to earn money.
I knew I'd never be making money but I thought I would at least be comfortably able to live and research things that interest me. My goal now is to grind the 5 more years that I need until my assets are enough to be financially independent through passive income and then I can work fulltime on the research I'm interested in but pays less than my rent (again, my wife and I will never be able to afford a house here until we retire and move away from where the jobs are).

>>15055284
>I would like to do research later.
>Is it just because its hard to get a job / to get a position or is the work bad?
not him but I also did chemistry and now work in research in industry. It's doable but you should be aware that it's certainly not the easiest path towards earning a comfortable living, assuming that's what you care about the most. I consider myself lucky that I managed to get a research position straight after a masters. I earn a decent enough salary for my age and where I live (although that's UK so most wages are shit), but nothing exceptional. I could have earned more doing some generic shit like engineering, comp sci, finance or whatever, with a less competitive job market and less occupational hazards to boot - although the latter is part of the fun if you ask me.
The work is enjoyable but this depends a lot on where you work and how much you enjoy your field of study. As for difficulty getting a job, I'd say you need to be top 25% of your cohort grade-wise, and make a real effort to get some form of internship before you graduate for there to be any sort of guarantee.

The blades don't bend because of centrifugal force, they are rigid because of centrifugal force. If you lose that centrifugal force in flight, the blades will break off. The R22 manual says this blade stall occurs at 80% plus 2% per thousand feet of density altitude. Different for different machines. Basically:
>Centrifugal force gives the blades their STRENGTH in flight.
>Bernoulli's Principle and Newton's Third Law creates the force which lift the blades (and helicopter)
If you lose that centrifugal force with the weight of the helicopter on them, they will flap up until they are, uh, mechanically separated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The rotating blades of a helicopter produce very high centrifugal loads on the rotor head and blade attachment assemblies. As a matter of interest, centrifugal loads may be from 6 to 12 tons at the blade root of two to four passenger helicopters. Larger helicopters may develop up to 40 tons of centrifugal load on each blade root. In rotary-wing aircraft, centrifugal force is the dominant force affecting the rotor system. All other forces act to modify this force.

When the rotor blades are at rest, they droop due to their weight and span. In fully articulated systems, they rest against a static or droop stop which prevents the blade from descending so low it will strike the aircraft (or ground!). When the rotor system begins to turn, the blade starts to rise from the static position because of the centrifugal force. At operating speed, the blades extend straight out even though they are at flat pitch and are not producing lift.

As the helicopter develops lift during takeoff and flight, the blades rise above the "straight out" position and assume a coned position. Amount of coning depends on RPM, gross weight, and G-Forces experienced during flight. If RPM is held constant, coning increases as gross weight and G-force increase. If gross weight and G-forces are constant, decreasing RPM will cause increased coning. Excessive coning can occur if RPM gets too low, gross weight is too high, or if excessive G-forces are experienced. Excessive coning can cause undesirable stresses on the blade and a decrease of total lift because of a decrease in effective disk area:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15070786
>when they are borderline impossible to work with?
They are pretty much the best to work with.

They are just
>q = cos(t)+i·sin(t)
where i is the normalized angle axis and t is the angle of rotation.
A rotation is performed via
>v \mapsto (1/q)*v*q

Often the information packaged into a 3x3 cosine matrix is useful, but for any frequently performed propagation, you best do it with quaternions

>>15070801
The rules for using quaternions to rotate are secretly the rules for multiplying SU(2) matrices (which is a double cover of SO(3)). You can expand a general SU(2) matrix into a sum of the identity matrix and the 3 Pauli matrices and those are your 4 unit quaternions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15073250
Let x = a*b*c*d*......
So x = 0 mod a, and mod b, mod c, etc.
So x+1 = 1 mod a, b c, d, etc, since a, b, c, d, etc are greater than 1 (otherwise it would be trivial). Therefore a, b, c, d, etc do not divide x+1.

the factorial n! is contained in
[eqn]\bigcap_{m\in\mathbb{N}_n}{m\mathbb{N}}=lcm(\mathbb{N}_n)\mathbb{N}[/eqn]
But we know that for all [math]m\in\mathbb{N}_n[/math][math]lcm(\mathbb{N})_n+1\cap m\mathbb{N}=\emptyset[/math]

That's not the proof. The proof says if you have a finite collection of prime numbers and assume that there are no other primes, multiplying them together and adding one creates a new number which is not divisible by any of the primes in your finite collection which means the new number has to be a prime outside of your collection which is a contradiction.
In more detail the product of a finite collection of numbers plus one is not divisible by any of the numbers in that collection as it has a reminder of one in division with each of these numbers.
Your observation is well put as it highlitghts exactly this fact

>Two other bits of evidence from HBD. First, larger-brained men have a 10 IQ point advantage in visuospatial ability over women, but verbal abilities are at best equal. >Apart from auxological factors, which was emphasized by Richard Lynn, performance also increases with greater training, an observation that was stressed more by James Flynn. One study (Armstrong et al., 2014) discovered a correlation between the FLynn effect on various tests, and the extent to which said tests are rule-dependent. Rule-dependent tests, in turn, benefit from retesting effects and the progressively greater emphasis on abstract thinking skills in schooling during the course of the 20th century. >Verbal skills, in contrast, benefit little if at all from greater brain size, and children in the developed world were already getting very stringently trained on it even a century ago. >How do you prove that an object is perfectly round?

>To prove that an object is perfectly round, you can use a number of different methods. One way to do this is to measure the object's diameter in multiple places using a ruler or caliper, and then compare the measurements to see if they are all equal. If the measurements are all the same, it is likely that the object is perfectly round.

>Another way to test the roundness of an object is to use a roundness tester, which is a specialized tool that is designed to measure the roundness of an object. This tool typically consists of a rotating spindle with a stylus that is used to trace the contour of the object being tested. By analyzing the trace left by the stylus, the roundness tester can determine the degree of roundness of the object.

>Another method that can be used to test the roundness of an object is to roll the object along a flat surface and observe its movement. If the object rolls smoothly and consistently without wobbling or deviating from its path, it is likely to be perfectly round.

>Finally, you can also use a high-resolution 3D scanner to create a digital model of the object and then use computer software to analyze the model to determine its roundness. This method is highly accurate and can be used to measure the roundness of objects with a high degree of precision.
